Sure, when they do it and no one is there (or just a civilian there), then it would be innocent until proven guilty, but when it’s done in front of a cop and/or against a cop, then you are a criminal on the spot.

Come back with facts before you blow shit out of your ass.

I would still prefer you actually talk to an officer about this before you decide you need to continue this debate. Before you say “wtf noob, I don’t see you talking to any”, several of my family members (3 of my uncles, 2 aunts, 1 cousin) are police officers, and I like to talk to them about:

What their job is like

How it feels to them to do it

What they experience

Things like that. Please try my suggestion. If you don’t I will simply ignore your posts.[/quote]

Believe it or not police officers are not the authority, although sometimes they think they are. And even if you commit a crime in front of an officer there is still the presumption of innocence unless proven guilty. If that were not true there would be no court trial and they would be jailed immediately. Since you are obliviously getting upset because you aren’t getting your own way I welcome you to prove me wrong with something other than your own opinion.

INNOCENCE, PRESUMPTION OF - The indictment or formal charge against any person is not evidence of guilt. Indeed, the person is presumed by the law to be innocent. The law does not require a person to prove his innocence or produce any evidence at all. The Government has the burden of proving a person guilty beyond a reasonable doubt, and if it fails to do so the person is (so far as the law is concerned) not guilty.
Find me an exception in the law that takes your constitution right of a trial by court away, please?

It is all about assumptions and assertions. An assumption is a position that is not proven but because of the circumstances can be considered correct. An assertion is a claim made justifying the assumption. Now when the arresting officer cites you or charges you with something he is swearing to the courts that there is sufficient evidence to prove his assertion. After that you can either accept the charge(s) as being true or not and plead guilty or not guilty, when you plead not guilty you are challenging the prosecution’s assumption. Your presumption will prevail unless the party making the assertion can provide the link between the evidence presented and its claim. Without evidence a claim can not be proven and your presumption wins.

item.dc:creator: @MastrChief MastrChief
item.description:
@MastrChief wrote:

Please don’t take this debate the wrong way as: “Omfg PaulT you fag gtfo nobody gives a shit what you have to say”, because thats not how it is if the is how it appeared to you.

First, nobody is a criminal in that video, they are suspects.

They became criminals when they:

Failed to comply with the orders of the officer

Resisted arrest

Fled the scene

When the officer is there witnessing it and so is the entire public, that makes them instantly criminals

To stop people from running from the police all reasonable force must be used, I agree. Yet reasonable force in this circumstance, where the officer is arresting people for skateboarding which is a victimless crime, seems like it should not be very much force at all.

The officer is allowed to use the proper amount of force to catch the criminal when fleeing. In this case it would be restraint. They were resisting arrest and he used the necessary method to try and keep them at the scene.

Also, you confuse punishment, which is issued by a judge in a court of law, with preventative measures taken by police to detain a suspect, which are not ever to be punitive in nature. In this case excess force may or may not have been used, that I cannot say for certain, however I can say for sure that there are much better places for that police officer to be and more helpful things for him to be doing for society. When you break the law and you are proven guilty a judge decides what punishment you deserve.

I think I already summed that up.

There are laws in this country that are incorrect and wrong. For example the rich are protected against the law while the poor are subject to the whim of the rich, drug addicts are treated as criminals instead of people who are sick, and groups such as blacks, gays, hispanics, and other minorities have been systematically discriminated against, and still are, under law. These are but a few small examples, there are countless others of the law protecting large corporations before the individual person, of the law bending to the will of those who can afford a certain lawyer, of politicians citing "Executive privelage" and etc..

I agree with you on the first part, but on the case of drugs, if it has been made a law not to do it, and you are caught doing it, you are breaking the law and will be dealt with accordingly.

I hate the police because they have chosen to become police officers even while they have the knowledge of the unfair and ridiculous laws in this country. Drug laws are a good example because prohibition laws have been shown to be ineffective at helping people.

I think I also already summed this one up too. People join the force for a few reasons:

The pay is pretty good I hear

They want to help make community’s better for the law abiding citizens

And whatever else…

If the police did not enforce the unjust laws then perhaps the kids in that video might have had enough respect for the force to simply go skateboard somewhere else after being asked. And, no matter how much they aggravated the cop, he should not have reacted in the violent impulsive way he did.

I am willing to bet those kids really didn’t give a rat’s ass anyway. A lot of kids these days don’t seem to care unless they get in trouble. They become criminals by their actions and the cop at least tried to use the necessary force the catch them.

Right, the police can't read minds. Yet they can go and patrol somewhere with high crime rates. I have said it before and I'll say it over and over if I have to, but there are many places where you can stand around and watch violent crime take place like clockwork, man. Some of these places aren't too far from where I live. The police just can't be pissed to go into the bad neighborhoods because they are afraid, just like anybody else.

And you want to know why they are afraid? They usually get shot, and sometimes killed. I think its fair to stay alive and out of the area until called upon for duty.

I do write letters to my elected officials on issues I am passionate about, so please do not take that kind of pretentious peachy tone with me, especially not in a debate, an exchange of ideas, such as I hope we are engaged in at the moment. I don't blame all problems on the police, but if they decided to stop enforcing dumb laws there wouldn't be much the politicians could do about it.

Then they are the ones you should be blaming, not the law enforcement.

They simply do as they are told, or they lose their job.

Abraham Lincoln said:
“A Prohibition law strikes a blow at the very principles upon which our government was founded.”

“To Protect and Serve” often translates into harass and control. Protecting the peace is not synonymous or equivalent to the enforcement of the law. Ordinary citizens live lives of voluntary respect for most laws. The threat of punishment or the fear of penalty does not infuse moral conduct. I don’t blame all problems on the police, but if they decided to stop enforcing dumb laws there wouldn’t be much the politicians could do about it.
